column2: Construct an ontology focused on the following: membership. Provide it in valid Turtle/RDF format, excluding any extra text.
column3: ```@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> .@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .@prefix xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> .@prefix mem: <http://www.example.com/membership#> .mem:Membership rdf:type rdfs:Class .mem:memberID rdf:type rdf:Property ;    rdfs:domain mem:Membership ;    rdfs:range xsd:string .mem:startDate rdf:type rdf:Property ;    rdfs:domain mem:Membership ;    rdfs:range xsd:date .mem:endDate rdf:type rdf:Property ;    rdfs:domain mem:Membership ;    rdfs:range xsd:date .mem:hasMembership rdf:type rdf:Property ;    rdfs:domain mem:Person ;    rdfs:range mem:Membership .mem:Person rdf:type rdfs:Class .mem:firstName rdf:type rdf:Property ;    rdfs:domain mem:Person ;    rdfs:range xsd:string .mem:lastName rdf:type rdf:Property ;    rdfs:domain mem:Person ;    rdfs:range xsd:string .```In this RDF/Turtle representation, a fictional `mem:` namespace is used to represent the membership ontology. It has two main classes: `mem:Membership` and `mem:Person`, with properties such as `mem:memberID`, `mem:startDate`, `mem:endDate`, `mem:hasMembership`, `mem:firstName`, and `mem:lastName` that describe the properties of membership and person respectively.
